title: Electric PE - work done on particles 2 and 3

content.question: Three charged particles, Particle <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, Particle <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, and Particle <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, have the same mass and charge as each other. Initially, Particle <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is by itself and is fixed in place as shown in the figure labeled “Particle <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>.” Next, Particle <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is moved by an external force from far away to a distance <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math> to the right of Particle <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, as shown in the figure labeled “Particles <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.” The external force does an amount of work <math alttext="W sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> to move Particle <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> into the position shown. Finally, Particle <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> is moved by an external force from far away to a distance <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math> to the right of Particle <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, as shown in the figure labeled “Particles <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>.” This time the external force does an amount of work <math alttext="W sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> to move Particle <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> into the position shown. How do <math alttext="W sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="W sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> compare to each other, and what evidence or reasoning supports the comparison?

choices.label: <math alttext="W sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="W sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> are equal. Particles <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> have the same mass and charge.

<math alttext="W sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="W sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> are equal. Particles <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> have the same charge, and the spacing between adjacent particles is the same.

<math alttext="W sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> is greater than <math alttext="W sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. Both particles <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> exert repulsive electrostatic forces on Particle <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>.

<math alttext="W sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> is greater than <math alttext="W sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. The distance between particles <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> is greater than the distance between particles <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="W sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> is greater than <math alttext="W sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. Both particles <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> exert repulsive electrostatic forces on Particle <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
